## Installation

<span class = "label label-success"><i class = "fa fa-warning"></i></span> Version `0.1.1` sees great performance and security improvements, *upgrading is highly recommended.*

You can install echarts4r with `devtools` or `remotes` from Github, Bitbucket or Coding. The latter is specifically for China, as the package is large download from Mainland can be long from outside the firewall.

```{r, eval=FALSE}
# install.packages("devtools")
devtools::install_github("JohnCoene/echarts4r") # github
```

```{r, eval=FALSE}
# install.packages("remotes")
remotes::install_bitbucket("JohnCoene/echarts4r") # bitbucket
```

```{r, eval=FALSE}
# install.packages("remotes")
remotes::install_git("https://git.coding.net/JohnCoene/echarts4r.git") # coding.net
```

## Features

Some of the features:

* 33 chart types
* Animations
* Brush & sliders
* WebGL support
* Plugins included
* Shiny proxies
* themes

## Examples

Some of what you can do with `echarts4r`, see the guide for more.

```{r}
library(echarts4r)

# with negative
USArrests %>% 
  dplyr::mutate(
    State = row.names(.),
    Rape = -Rape
  ) %>% 
  e_charts(State) %>% 
  e_area(Murder) %>%
  e_bar(Rape, name = "Sick basterd", x.index = 1) %>% # second y axis 
  e_mark_line("Sick basterd", data = list(type = "average")) %>% 
  e_mark_point("Murder", data = list(type = "max")) %>% 
  e_tooltip(trigger = "axis")

# 3D bars
url <- paste0("https://ecomfe.github.io/echarts-examples/",
              "public/data-gl/asset/data/population.json")
data <- jsonlite::fromJSON(url)
data <- as.data.frame(data)
names(data) <- c("lon", "lat", "value")

data %>% 
  e_charts(lon) %>% 
  e_geo_3d() %>% 
  e_bar_3d(lat, value, coord.system = "geo3D") %>% 
  e_visual_map()
```
